ratings.question_text: Your level of engagement with the course was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of intellectual challenge of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the workload of this course was:

narratives.question_text: What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
comments: I gained a working knowledge in the beginning of calculus, and I feel like I understand it quite well now.
I learned about Calculus and developed insights on population models.

I developed my skills in solving numerous problems in an inter-related field of calc. I learnt how to differentiate and integrate a range of equations, how to find the slope at a certain point and how this relates to the derivative, second derivative etc.
It helped me revise my calc skills and be prepare me for classes such as econ

I learned how to do basic calculus, such as taking derivatives, integrals, and applying those concepts to problems like related rates and many more. College math is very different from high school math as the classes are MUCH faster-paced, and the course isn't as structured as AP calculus. This forced me to do a lot of learning outside of the classroom with the textbook. However, what my professor did with the Skeleton notes was pretty great.
my math skills.
I developed my math skills a lot
Diffrentials
Problem solving, learned more about calculus

Aside from developing skills in math, this course helped me develop new methods of studying and thinking critically to understand academic fields that I have found myself struggling with in the past. It taught me how to utilize all my resources (such as not just my notes but also use the textbook, peer tutoring, the internet, etc.) and it taught me the value of sitting down and setting a daily schedule so that I can take time to study.
Although I already took Calc I in high school, this class was a great refresher for what I had learned. I also learned the concepts in new ways.
I did not learn very much, because I had taken a similar math course before.
Derivatives, Integration, and applications of both. How to use Calculus to model.

I learned how to take derivatives, and how to use derivatives to analyze the behavior of a function. I also learned how to apply calculus to real-life situations, such as infection rates and population dynamics.
How to study effectively on my own.
applications of basic calculus
Single variable calculus: limits, derivatives, integrals, optimization, and some other applications

narratives.question_text: What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
comments: This course is quite strong, but I think it could benefit by having more peer tutoring opportunities. Also, offering class skeletons to all students for the entirety of the course would be very beneficial.
The in-class practice and problem sets are not an accurate reflection of the exams. Therefore, practicing for midterms and finals can be hard.

Strengths are the assessment break down, there is a good balance of the weighting of homework, midterms and the final. The course was well taught and it can be improved by having a more comprehensive set of revision materials for the exams.
It covers a wide range of topics but I wish the course went on a more typical path.

Strengths: passionate professor, good outline the units that we had to learn (I loved how closely we followed the textbook).

Weaknesses: I wish there was more high-school type homework, as in more rote practice. I understand the goal of the psets is to make you deeply deeply think about the skills and topics learned in class, but also, rote practice will make students understand the topic more than anything. You can't understand it if you're not good at it. So instead of these insanely long and difficult psets, maybe cut down the psets by a bit, but also assign worksheets or txtbook problems for simple practice.

Additionally, I wish we could get an answer key to the psets after we submit them. I always got feedback on what i did wrong, but never knew what the actual right answer was.
strengths were it was engaging to the whole time.

I think this course went very fast but I liked when my professor Brett gave us paper notes packets to fill out. This really allowed me to pay attention to learning in class rather than writing down notes instead of listening.
Good

This course was very strong in that it was very well taught by professors, peer tutors, and teaching fellows. However, the course was weak in that many students found certain peer tutors to be much more helpful than others, and some students found that Ximera was not the most effective method to engage with the material.
This course required a ability to think on the spot specially when taking Exams
I liked the professor and the class size. One issue I had with the class was the first pset, which was unnecessarily difficult and touched on topics we did not discuss in the class.

This class was not very interesting and the problem sets were hard, and graded very harshly. If you go to office hours you should be okay, but it is still more difficult than it needs to be to get a good problem set grade.

The material was extremely rushed at the end of the semester. The problem sets didn't actually help develop understanding of the material in a way that was effective. They were also graded extremely harshly without clear explanation as to why or how to solve problems correctly. Solutions were never posted after submission and grading so students could see and study how to solve problems. 
More examples should be shown in class to give students the tools needed to tackle the problem sets and Ximera was the way that students learned the material.

Strengths: even if you aren't necessarily a "math" person, this course will pique your curiosity. 

Weaknesses: 
 - I would have benefitted from more practice problems during class 
 - the problem sets and exams are graded for extremely minute issues, and graders aren't very forgiving
 - the difficulty level of problem set questions is not relevant to exams and topics covered in class
It can be improved by having the professor teach the material instead of simply learning on our own through Ximera.

Strengths: structure is conducive to learning bit by bit, Brett is a great teacher, there is a lot of additional support (peer tutors with office hours, review sessions, TA's, ...)
Weaknesses: feels a lot like a high school class (worksheets, daily home works, weekly Psets, etc), which is helpful to cover the material, but it also allows you to be passive and tune out.

narratives.question_text: Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
comments: I would. This course is very thorough.
I would recommend this course to someone that needs it as a prerequisite for their major. It is a hard course that requires a lot of practice and time.
Unless you absolutely have to take math, I wouldnt recommend. Theres a lot of work to do and sometimes the concepts arent explained well in class.
Yes I would recommend this course to another student as they would improve their overall grasp on the subject and it is a rewarding subject to understand if you apply yourself.
Take it as your math requirement class!
Yes, it was very helpful in refining my calculus skills.

Yes, I would. I never took calculus in high school, so this was my first introduction to it. I would say supplementing your learning in the classroom with taking notes on the txtbook and doing additional practice problems is vital to success.
yes because it is a challenging math course
Yes I would I learned more math and got my math requirement done for my major.
A requirement
Yes, because it is required

I would most definitely recommend this class to another student, as I consider it to be a good introduction to the academic culture at Yale. It is well taught yet maintains the difficulty and necessity of self-study that will aid students in transitioning from high school to university life. Also, most students have had some introduction to calculus in high school but don't fully understand how to utilize it; this class does a great job of helping students deeply understand introductory calculus.
Yes I would it was really interesting
I would recommend this course to another student if it is required for a major or a class. Otherwise, if you really like math I would recommend this class to really solidify the basics of calculus.
Yes, if you need to meet a math requirement.
I would only recommend this course to a student who has taken Calculus before.
If you don't love math but need to fulfill QR or major requirements, I recommend this course.
Only if needed for your major
Yes if you have to take a math requirement or enjoy math. It is a well structured class.
